___name.description: Do you use "template morphing" in your analysis, e.g. to model a systematic uncertainty in the statistical model?
___name.title: Template Morphing

___twiki_read.description: Have you read the SC recommendation TWiki pages on systematic uncertainties?
___twiki_read.title: TWiki Pages Read

___name.description: Does your analysis include "cross-checks" of your method, e.g. the verification of a technique on a subsidiary set of data? If the answer is "No": Are you deriving a systematic uncertainty on your main measurement from the level of agreement you observe in the cross-check? What would you have done if the cross-check failed (e.g. p-value below 0.01, or other pre-defined criterion)?
___name.title: Crosschecks

___failure_procedure.title: Procedure in case of cross-check failure

___consideration.description: Have you considered that systematic uncertainties constrained by sideband measurements in the data, and whose estimate thus depends on the size of the analyzed dataset, should be treated as statistical uncertainties?
___consideration.title: Consideration of Systematic Uncertainties

___recommendations_awareness.description: If a systematic effect is included as nuisance parameter in the model, are you aware that the SC recommends the use of Gamma or Log-Normal priors instead of truncated Gaussians?
___recommendations_awareness.title: Awareness of SC recommendations

___discovery.description: Take a second and read the TWiki Pages on Search Procedures, Sensitivity Calculations, and Look-Elsewhere Effect (if applicable)?
___discovery.title: Discovery

___usage.description: Does the analysis include discovery-related statements, such as citing p-values of the null hypothesis or a "significance"? If the answer is "No", please proceed with the next section.
___usage.title: Usage

___name.description: Do you account for the look-elsewhere effect?
___name.title: Look-Elsewhere Effect

___name.description: To evaluate the p-value(s) of the null hypothesis, what test statistic was used?
___name.title: Test Statistics

___twiki_read.description: Have you read the discovery-related TWiki pages mentioned above (if applicable)?
___twiki_read.title: TWiki Pages Read

___usage.description: Does the analysis include fitting of data distributions? If the answer is "No", please proceed with the next section.
___usage.title: Usage of fitting of data distributions

___name.description: Do you perform a goodness-of-fit test for the fit(s)? If the answer is "Yes" or "Undecided", please provide additional information and the resultung p-values(s).
___name.title: Goodness-Of-Fit Test

items.description: Which test statistic are you using to perform the fit(s)?
items.title: Test Statistic

___reason.title: What drove you to this particular choice?

___name.description: In case you perform a fit to the background shape with a function: How do you choose the functional form?
___name.title: Background Shape Choice

___name.description: Are any of the parameters returned by the fit close (less than 3 sigma) to their physical or pre-defined boundary?
___name.title: Parameter Boundaries

___toy_pull_distribution.title: Check of Pull Distributions in Toy Experiments

___name.description: Do you check that the pull distribution in toy experiments is distributed as expected for an unbiased method (mean 0, width 1)?
___name.title: Pull Distributions in Toy Experiments

items.description: How do you choose the fitting model?
items.title: Fitting Model

___name.description: In case you are using the returned parameters in other parts of your analysis: are you accounting for the covariance matrix (error and off-diagonal correlation terms) of the parameter uncertainties?
___name.title: Covariance Matrix Check

___fit_function.title: Fit Function: Choice of Number of Parameters

___name.description: In case you perform a fit using a functional form which exists for many different number of parameters (such as polynomials): How are you choosing the number of parameters?
___name.title: Fit Function

___general.description: Please get familiar with the Statistics Committee TWiki Page, which for example links Frequently Asked Questions, and a Page of Statistics-related References you can cite. You might also want to take a quick look at the Statistics Discussions Hypernews Forum and add the Committee's mailing list cms-statistics-committee@cern.ch to your contacts.
___general.title: General Information

___past_interaction.description: Have you interacted with the Statistics Committee in the past (via email, HN, or in person) to discuss an issue with a CMS analysis?
___past_interaction.title: Past Interaction

___faq_awareness.description: Are you aware that the Statistics Committee has a TWiki page which links a number of short documents describing recommendations for statistical techniques, including e.g., Frequently Asked Questions, and a page of statistics-related references you can cite?
___faq_awareness.title: FAQ Awareness

___forum_awareness.description: Are you aware that the Statistics Committee will make an effort to promptly answer your question on statistics issues if sent via the Statistics Discussions Hypernews forum, or to the Committee's mailing list cms-statistics-committee@cern.ch?
___forum_awareness.title: Forum/List Awareness

___forum_subscription.description: Have you subscribed yet to the Statistics Discussions Hypernews forum (if not, we suggest that you do)?
___forum_subscription.title: Forum/List Subscription

___meetings_awareness.description: Are you aware that the Statistics Committee meets regularly (Vidyo only; look for announcement in Statistics Discussions HN forum) and that everybody is welcome to participate?
___meetings_awareness.title: Open Meetings Awareness

___other_stats.description: Take a second read the FAQ
___other_stats.title: Other Statistics Related Items

___faq_read.description: Did you check if one of the frequently asked questions apply to your analysis?
___faq_read.title: FAQ Read

___name.description: In case you use the results of another CMS analysis: how did you treat correlations from common systematic uncertainties and from potential overlap in the datasets?
___name.title: Combined Measurements

___name.description: Do you perform a blind analysis? If so, can you succinctly describe what was done?
___name.title: Blind Analysis

___name.description: In case you combine measurements in your analysis: what method is used?
___name.title: Combined Measurements

___multivariate.description: Take a second and read the SC TWiki Page on MVA Recommendations.
___multivariate.title: Multivariate Discriminants

___name.description: How do you make sure you are not affected by overtraining?
___name.title: Overtraining Checks

___name.description: Are you aware that some MVA techniques may classify data events as very signal-like if any of their variables take values in regions where the background training samples have no events?
___name.title: Null PDF

___usage.description: Are you using a multi-variate discriminant in your data analysis to discriminate between signal and background? If the answer is "No", please proceed with the next section.
___usage.title: Usage of multi-variante descriminant

___name.description: What software are you using?
___name.title: Options

___twiki_read.description: Have you read the TWiki mentioned above?
___twiki_read.title: TWiki Read

items.description: What type of discriminant do you use?
items.title: Used Type

___name.description: When training with more than one background, do you mix all samples in the proportions you expect in data?
___name.title: Background Mix

items.description: How do you make use of the MVA output in the analysis?
items.title: MVA Output Usage

items.description: Do you study the correlations and dependencies between the input variables?
items.title: Study of correlations/dependencies

items.description: How have you checked that the input variables, including their dependencies, are well-modeled?
items.title: Input Variable Checks

___name.description: Do you perform the following robustness check?
___name.title: Robustness Checks

___name.description: How do you select the input variables? Do you perform any pruning of your initial list of input variables, based on the correlations or dependencies between the input variables?
___name.title: Input Variable Selection

___analysis_title.title: If no CADI entry is available, please provide the title and applicable references

___unfolding.description: Take a second and read the SC Note on "Interim recommendations on unfolding techniques"
___unfolding.title: Unfolding

___usage.description: Is unfolding used in parts of the analysis? (If the answer is "No", please proceed with the next section)
___usage.title: Usage

items.description: Which unfolding technique are you using?
items.title: Technique

___bbb_discouragement_awareness.description: Are you aware that the SC discourages the use of bin-by-bin unfolding, or correction factors, and in general on techniques neglecting correlations?
___bbb_discouragement_awareness.title: Awareness of Discouragement of Bin-By-Bin Folding

___note_read.description: Have you read the SC note on Interim recommendations on unfolding techniques?
___note_read.title: Interim recommendations on unfolding techniques Read

___validation.title: How do you validate the unfolding procedure (e.g., comparison with other techniques, toy studies, etc.)?

___name.description: In case you apply weights to the number of observed (real data) events, e.g. to correct for trigger prescales.
___name.title: Event Weight Application

___feedback.description: You're almost there! Just some final questions that may help us to improve our service.
___feedback.title: Comments and Feedback

___additional_comments.title: Do you have any additional comment related to the analysis? Is there a statistic-related element of your analysis not covered by this questionnaire?

___name.description: What statistical element of your analysis is not yet frozen (what changes can be expected)?
___name.title: Subjects to Change

___feedback.title: Do you have a suggestion for improving this questionnaire? Do you have a suggestion for improving interaction with the CMS Statistics Committee in general or documentation of statistical recommendations?

___citation.title: Citation of limit or two-sided confidence interval

___name.description: Will you cite a limit or a two-sided confidence interval?
___name.title: Citation

___usage.description: Does the analysis include the setting of limits on some parameter or placing a confidence interval on some parameter? (If the answer is "No", please proceed with the next section.)
___usage.title: Usage of confidence intervals and limits

items.description: What software tool are you using for your confidence interval calculations?
items.title: Software

___recommendation_awareness.description: If you are using a Bayesian technique, are you aware that the SC recommends to perform a prior sensitivity analysis, both on the PDFs of parameters describing the systematic uncertainties (nuisance parameters) and on the PDF of the parameter to be estimated?
___recommendation_awareness.title: Awareness of Recommendation of Prior Sensitivity Analysis

___name.description: Mark the approach(es) you are using
___name.title: Options

items.description: Mark the approach(es) you are using
items.title: Approaches

___name.description: In the case of frequentist/CLs confidence interval construction: which test statistic do you use? As an example of the detail you should provide: "the HCG choice is qmu = -2 Ln[L(mu, theta_mu_* )/L(mu* ,theta* )], with 0 < mu* < mu at the denominator, and the numerator has nuisances set at conditional ML estimate for data at given mu, theta_mu_*"(If you chose "other", please specify the test statistic used)
___name.title: Statistics

___support_awareness.description: Are you aware that the Statistics Committee provides support and a simple recipe to include the derivation of Feldman-Cousins confidence intervals in RooStats jobs that are currently used to compute CLs limits?
___support_awareness.title: Awareness of Support by the Statistics Committee

___theory_error.title: Theory Error in Signal Cross Section

___name.description: In case you convert a limit on a signal cross section into a limit on the mass (or another parameter; we call it "mass" here): how do you account for the theory error on the signal cross section?
___name.title: Theory Error

___name.description: In the case toy data is generated as part of the limit setting procedure - e.g. to determine the test statistic distribution or to compute the expected limit / expected limit bands - please specify how the nuisance parameter are chosen for the toys:
___name.title: Toy Data

___atlas_cms_agreement.description: Are you aware of the agreement between ATLAS and CMS regarding limit setting?
___atlas_cms_agreement.title: ATLAS-CMS agreement
